secondScreen.content1: Transform your friend from couch potato to gold medalist - sign them up by starting their Randolympic campaign!
secondScreen.content2: Show them you believe in their potential, it will be a big surprise and a huge compliment.
secondScreen.content3: Get them out the couch, giving them a fitness program that finally works.
secondScreen.content4: Motivate them, managing their progress and cheering them on all the way.
secondScreen.content5: The best of all: a lot of fun for everyone involved !

ourBeliefs.content2: We believe that the random nature of sports has a unique power to bring people together. In a world filled with conflicts and divisions, our events offer a chance to unite humankind. By competing together, we demonstrate that athletic challenges can bridge cultures, nations, and beliefs, showing that competition can foster connection instead of division.
ourBeliefs.content3: Everyone is welcome to participate, regardless of nationality, race, values, religion, political views, gender, or sexual orientation. Our host cities ensure that all participants can join by providing the necessary support, including visas. We stand firmly against any form of exclusion based on identity, beliefs, religion, race, gender, or any other defining trait, ensuring equal opportunity for everyone.
ourBeliefs.content4: Transparency is at the heart of everything we do. As far as possible, we use open-source technology for payments and communication to ensure openness and security. Our democratic system gives equal rights and voting power to every nation and participant, fostering a fair, accountable, and inclusive environment for all.

economics.subtitle1: Our organization has four types of income sources.
economics.subtitle2: Most payments are published on the blockchain.
economics.content1: Income generated from donations made by supporters to campaigns for athletes.
economics.content2: Even if athletes do not make it to the games, whether due to injury, a personal decision, or simply not being randomly selected, these funds contribute to the overall success of the Randolympics. These donations help to cover organizational costs and ensure...
economics.content3: Broadcasting Rights involve granting media entities the permission to cover and report on Randolympics events.
economics.content4: These rights can be acquired by various media platforms, such as:
economics.content5: YouTube Channels: Independent or corporate channels that wish to broadcast the events online.
economics.content6: TikTok Influencers: Content creators on TikTok who want to provide live...
economics.content7: Sponsorship is a significant source of income where various entities can sponsor different aspects of the Randolympics. This includes:
economics.content8: Events: Companies or brands can sponsor individual events within the Randolympics.
economics.content9: National Teams: Sponsorship deals can be made with national teams, allowing sponsors to have their...
economics.content10: Loans are a source of income for the Randolympics organization where they receive funding from loan givers.
economics.content11: These loans are provided with the expectation that the loan givers will receive their money back along with yearly interest. The terms and conditions of the loan, including the interest rate and repayment schedule, are agreed upon at the time of the...

howItWorks.content1: Help your friend get back into the shape they had years ago! They'll appreciate the push - and the confidence you have in them - to take on such a HUGE challenge. Nominate a friend or even a celebrity to compete, and rally supporters and donations to boost their chances!
howItWorks.content2: One hundred athletes are randomly selected in each country based on campaign success and support. The top 50 men and 50 women form the national teams.
howItWorks.content3: During the ceremony, each athlete is randomly assigned between three and seven different sports to compete in. Let the games begin!

CFR.title2: Can a supporter of a campaign attend the Randolympics ?
CFR.title5: Who can participate as an athlete?
CFR.title6: How can I get more supporters for my campaign ?
CFR.title7: Why is there a minimum support amount of USD 1?
CFR.title8: How do you verify that each supporter is unique?
CFR.title9: Can I create more than one campaign?
CFR.title10: Can I be both an athlete and a supporter at the same time?
CFR.title11: What happens to the money raised through donations?
CFR.title12: How does a celebrity campaign differ from a normal campaign?
CFR.title13: What campaign will succeed? How does the National Ranking work?
CFR.title14: What happens if athletes cannot attend due to injury or personal reasons?
CFR.content1: Yes, absolutely! Everyone is welcome to join and be a part of this incredible adventure. Supporters, friends, and fans are all encouraged to come and cheer on their athletes, experience the excitement, and enjoy the community atmosphere.
CFR.content2: Anyone can start a campaign! All you need is a friend who believes in you and at least one dollar to get started. It's a simple way to motivate someone to achieve extraordinary goals
CFR.content3: Anyone can participate as an athlete! The only requirements are that you have a valid passport and are at least 12 years old. There’s no upper age limit, so no one is too old or too young to join!
CFR.content4: To gather more supporters, share your campaign on social media, send personalized messages to your network on WhatsApp, and spread the word in your gym, sports club, or community. The more people know, the more they can support!
CFR.content5: This small minimum amount is a safeguard against fake or automated accounts. It helps ensure that each supporter is a real, unique person genuinely interested in backing an athlete.
CFR.content6: We verify each athlete through their valid passport, ensuring that there is no way to manipulate the system or create duplicate entries.
CFR.content7: Yes, you can create as many campaigns as you want! Starting a campaign is a huge compliment to a friend—a sign that you believe in their potential to achieve extraordinary things. Campaigns also make a thoughtful and inspiring gift for special occasions, like birthdays.
CFR.content8: Yes, you can! You can participate as an athlete in a campaign set up by your friend while also creating multiple campaigns yourself to support others. Your involvement can be as broad and supportive as you want it to be.
CFR.content9: If the campaign is successful, the raised money will be transferred to the athlete to support their journey to the Randolympics, including training, equipment, and other preparation expenses. Additionally, if supporters wish to attend the event, up to three supporters from the campaign will receive a contribution towards their flight tickets to help them be part of the experience. If the campaign does not succeed in getting the athlete into an event, the donations will be used to ensure the event runs smoothly and is well-funded.
CFR.content10: A celebrity campaign is similar to a normal campaign, but with a few key differences. Unlike regular campaigns, the contact details and email address of the celebrity may not be known to the person creating the campaign. If the celebrity decides to consider attending the Randolympics and wants to log in to their account, they need to announce their interest on social media and then contact both the National President and the campaign creator. They will coordinate and provide a secure login method for the celebrity to access their campaign account safely.
CFR.content11: A campaign's success depends on its position in the National Ranking, which is determined through a randomized ranking process. Each campaign is ranked based on three factors: the total amount of money raised, the number of unique supporters, and a random number between 0 and 1. These factors are combined to generate a final ranking for each campaign. To form each National Team, the top 50 men and top 50 women with the highest rankings are selected. However, teams must be balanced regarding weight categories, with each of the three weight groups equally represented. This balance requirement means that a campaign ranked 48th might not make the team if that weight category is already filled, while a campaign ranked 53rd could be included if that weight group is underrepresented.
CFR.content12: If an athlete in the top 50 cannot attend the Randolympics due to injury, personal reasons, or other circumstances, they will be replaced by the next highest-ranked athlete from their weight category. This ensures that the team remains balanced and filled. Athletes ranked just above 50 still have a chance to participate if there are dropouts or changes in the roster, providing opportunities for those with a slightly lower ranking to make it to the games.
CFR.content13: Not directly from the Randolympics organization, but each athlete is free to sign sponsorship agreements. Unlike other events, there are no restrictions on how athletes dress or what brands they can display and when. Some events might go viral, and an athlete could become famous for a specific competition, opening up more sponsorship and earning opportunities.

EC.title16: Can athletes request to change their assigned sports?
EC.title18: How many sports are assigned to an athlete?
EC.title19: What types of sports will be included in the Randolympics?
EC.title20: What kind of training support is provided to athletes before the competition?
EC.title21: Are there any specific rules that athletes need to follow during competitions?
EC.title22: What is the event structure or setup?
EC.title23: What safety measures are in place for competitions?
EC.title24: Can supporters participate in any events or activities?
EC.content14: No, once sports are assigned during the opening ceremony, they cannot be changed. The random assignment is part of the challenge and spirit of the Randolympics.
EC.content15: No, participation in any competition is entirely voluntary. We prioritize the safety and well-being of all athletes. If an athlete feels uncomfortable or unprepared for any assigned sport, they are not required to compete. Our goal is to encourage participation and challenge limits, but never at the cost of an athlete's comfort or safety.
EC.content16: It depends, but typically an athlete will be assigned between 4 to 6 sports to compete in during the Randolympics.
EC.content17: The event will feature a wide range of sports, including endurance, strength, team-based, and individual competitions. The list on our webpage here might change as we get closer to the event.
EC.content18: Each athlete is responsible for their own training. Support from their campaign and community is encouraged.
EC.content19: Yes, each sport has its own set of rules and regulations that must be followed to ensure fair play. These rules will be explained in detail before each competition.
EC.content20: In every competition, each country is represented by one team or athlete. There are three types of events:
EC.content21: Races like marathons: These allow up to 64 competitors in one race, resulting in a single winner.
EC.content22: Team sports like football or tennis: These are structured in a knockout format where winners advance to the next round until only four teams or athletes remain.
EC.content23: Races with heats like swimming: These involve multiple rounds with heats, leading to a final race to determine the winner.
EC.content24: All competitions are overseen by referees and safety officers. There will be medical staff on-site, and equipment will be inspected to ensure it meets safety standards.
EC.content25: Supporters are encouraged to participate in designated fan events and activities during the Randolympics. However, they cannot compete in the official sports events unless they are registered athletes.
EC.content26: We aim to plan sufficient time between two competitions to ensure athletes have time to rest and prepare. However, in extreme situations—such as a delay in the first competition and a traffic jam between venues—it is theoretically possible that an athlete may not be able to compete in the second event. Having good support can help manage such situations by quickly finding the venue and organizing transportation to minimize disruptions in such unlikely events.

SPM.title26: Who will have the broadcasting rights?
SPM.title27: How can I become a partner or sponsor?
SPM.title29: Can sponsors have exclusive rights to specific events?
SPM.title30: What branding opportunities are available for sponsors?
SPM.title31: Can media outlets report on the Randolympics without purchasing broadcasting rights?
SPM.content27: The broadcasting rights for the Randolympics will soon be sold in an online auction. This auction will sell the rights for each event in the main languages. After purchasing, the entity or person who acquires these rights will have the exclusive ability to report in that language from the event.
SPM.content28: We welcome potential partners and sponsors to join us in making the Randolympics a global success. If you are interested, please contact us through our Partner Inquiry Page for more information and to discuss opportunities.
SPM.content29: Sponsorship opportunities range from event sponsorships and digital content integration to on-site activations. We offer flexible packages tailored to the needs and goals of each sponsor. Contact us to explore how we can create a unique sponsorship package for your brand.
SPM.content30: Yes, sponsors can secure exclusive rights to specific events within the Randolympics. This includes branding, digital presence, and other unique promotional opportunities during the event. However, athletes retain the right to have their own sponsorships and display personal branding on their gear and uniforms.
SPM.content31: Sponsors can showcase their brands through event banners, digital streams, and social media channels. While event branding is available, keep in mind that athletes can feature their own sponsors and brands on their uniforms and during personal media appearances.
SPM.content32: Media outlets are welcome to cover the Randolympics through general news reporting. However, for live broadcasts or detailed event coverage in a specific language, they must acquire broadcasting rights through the auction process.

LCG.title33: How is the Global President elected?
LCG.title35: How are athletes selected for the Randolympics?
LCG.title36: How do we try to avoid corruption?
LCG.title38: What is the governance structure of Randolympics?
LCG.title39: How is compliance maintained within Randolympics?
LCG.content33: National Presidents are elected by athletes with an ongoing campaign and a valid passport for that country. If a candidate receives more than 120% of the votes compared to the current National President, the new candidate takes over the position.
LCG.content34: The Global President is elected similarly to the National Presidents, but in this case, the electors are the National Presidents from each country. A candidate must receive a vote total exceeding 120% of the current Global President's votes to be elected.
LCG.content35: Managers are selected by the Global President. The President appoints managers to various roles within the organization based on their expertise and the needs of Randolympics.
LCG.content36: Athletes are selected through a randomized national ranking system. This ranking considers the total amount of money raised, the number of unique supporters, and a random number to ensure a fair and balanced selection process.
LCG.content37: We aim to prevent corruption by ensuring maximum transparency. All payments, contracts, and financial agreements are made open and accessible to the public to maintain trust and accountability.
LCG.content38: We strive to execute as many transactions as possible via a blockchain. This ensures that all financial movements are traceable, verifiable, and secure, providing a high level of transparency.
LCG.content39: The governance structure of Randolympics includes the Global President, National Presidents, and appointed managers who oversee various functions of the organization. This structure ensures both global oversight and local representation, fostering fair and transparent management.
LCG.content40: Compliance is maintained through a set of established rules and guidelines that all participants, managers, and officials must follow. Regular audits and reviews are conducted to ensure adherence to these rules and to uphold the integrity of the Randolympics.

sixthScreen.title1: Join as National President or Manager
sixthScreen.title2: Are you passionate about sports and leadership? We are seeking motivated individuals to become National Presidents and Global Managers for Randolympics. This is your chance to represent your country or take on a global role in shaping the future of this movement.

contact.title2: Have a question or need more information?
contact.title3: Fill out the form below with your inquiry, and one of our team members will get back to you as soon as possible.

archery.subtitle1: Tests precision, focus, and technique in both individual and team formats.
archery.title1: Brief Overview of the Basic Rules for Archery
archery.desc1:
Distance: Shooting distances vary depending on the competition format and category.

Equipment: Archers must use approved bows and arrows. Equipment must meet specific regulations regarding size and materials.

Safety: Archers must follow safety protocols, including proper handling of equipment and maintaining a safe distance from the target area.

These rules ensure accuracy, fairness, and safety in archery competitions.

variations.title: Individual Archery
variations.desc:
Event: Archers compete individually to shoot arrows at a target from a set distance.
Competition Method: Each archer takes a series of shots at the target, aiming for the highest score based on accuracy. Points are awarded based on where the arrows land on the target, with the bullseye earning the highest points.

variations.title: Team Archery
variations.desc:
Event: Teams of archers compete together, with each team member taking shots to accumulate a combined score.
Competition Method: Teams shoot in rounds, with each member contributing to the total team score. The team with the highest combined score wins.
Scoring: Each team's score is the sum of the individual scores from each member’s shots.

swimming.subtitle1: Swimming test speed, technique, and endurance across different distances and strokes.
swimming.title1: Brief Overview of the Basic Rules for competitive swimming
swimming.desc1:
False Starts: A swimmer who leaves the starting block before the signal will be disqualified.

Turns and Finishes: Proper technique for turns and finishes must be followed for each stroke.

Underwater Distance: Swimmers cannot stay underwater beyond 15 meters after the start and each turn.

These rules ensure fairness, safety, and consistency in swimming competitions.

1. Freestyle: Any stroke is allowed, but the front crawl is typically used.
Swimmers must touch the wall at each turn and finish.
Part of the swimmer's body must break the surface throughout the race, except at the start and turns.

2. Backstroke: Swimmers must stay on their back except during turns.
They start in the water and push off the wall.
Flip turns are allowed, but swimmers must touch the wall on their back at the finish.

3. Breaststroke: Swimmers use simultaneous arm and leg movements (frog kick).
Both hands must touch the wall at the same time during turns and finishes.
The head must break the surface of the water during each stroke cycle.

4. Butterfly Both arms must move forward simultaneously over the water, with a dolphin kick.
Both hands must touch the wall at the same time during turns and finishes.

5. Individual Medley (IM) Swimmers perform each stroke (butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, freestyle) in the correct order.
They must touch the wall at each stroke transition.

6. Relays The swimmer in the pool must touch the wall before the next swimmer can start.
In medley relays, the stroke order is backstroke, breaststroke, butterfly, and freestyle.

variations.title: 50m Freestyle
variations.desc: A sprint race covering one pool length in a freestyle stroke, typically front crawl. Speed is critical.

variations.title: 100m Freestyle
variations.desc: Two lengths using freestyle stroke, a balance of speed and endurance.

variations.title: 200m Freestyle
variations.desc: Four pool lengths in freestyle, requiring strong pacing and efficient turns.

variations.title: 400m Freestyle
variations.desc: Eight lengths of the pool, emphasising endurance in freestyle.

variations.title: 1500m Freestyle
variations.desc: A long-distance event (30 lengths) in freestyle, requiring consistent pacing and stamina.

variations.title: 100m Backstroke
variations.desc: Two lengths of the pool in backstroke, where swimmers must start in the water facing the wall, using an alternating arm motion.

variations.title: 200m Backstroke
variations.desc: Four pool lengths using backstroke, focusing on maintaining strong technique and endurance.

variations.title: 100m Breaststroke
variations.desc: Two lengths using the breaststroke technique, with a frog-like kick and glide, emphasizing power and timing.

variations.title: 200m Breaststroke
variations.desc: Four lengths of breaststroke, demanding endurance while maintaining a smooth and powerful stroke.

variations.title: 100m Butterfly
variations.desc: Two lengths using butterfly stroke, characterized by simultaneous arm movements and a dolphin-like kick.

variations.title: 200m Butterfly
variations.desc: A longer event of four pool lengths in butterfly, requiring excellent rhythm and endurance.

variations.title: 200m Individual Medley
variations.desc: Four pool lengths where each stroke is swum for 50 meters: butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle.

variations.title: 400m Individual Medley
variations.desc: Eight lengths of the pool with each stroke swum for 100 meters in the same order: butterfly, backstroke, breaststroke, and freestyle.

variations.title: 4x100m Freestyle Relay
variations.desc: Four swimmers each swim 100m in freestyle. The next swimmer can start when the previous swimmer touches the wall.

variations.title: 4x200m Freestyle Relay
variations.desc: A longer relay where each swimmer swims 200m in freestyle.

variations.title: 4x100m Medley Relay
variations.desc: Four swimmers, each swimming one of the strokes in this order: backstroke, breaststroke, butterfly, and freestyle.

diving.subtitle1: Diving is a sport that combines athleticism, precision, and grace as athletes perform acrobatic jumps and flips from springboards or platforms, entering the water with minimal splash. The sport requires control, body awareness, and impeccable timing.
diving.desc1:
Divers are scored based on the difficulty of their dive and how well they execute it, considering factors like takeoff, flight, and entry into the water.

Dive Difficulty: Divers choose a list of dives, each assigned a degree of difficulty (DD) based on complexity. More difficult dives offer the potential for higher scores but also carry greater risk.

Judging: A panel of judges scores each dive based on execution and technique. Points are awarded for the takeoff, the aerial phase, and entry into the water.

Splash Control: A key element in diving is the entry into the water. A well-executed dive minimizes splash, as a cleaner entry is considered more controlled and aesthetically pleasing.

Diving is a test of both physical prowess and artistic presentation, with athletes combining athletic jumps, flips, and twists in a captivating display of skill.

variations.title: 3m Springboard Diving
variations.desc:
Athletes dive from a flexible board 3 meters above the water. The board allows divers to gain height with their jump, adding complexity to their dive.
Key Skills: Balance, precision, and control during takeoff and mid-air maneuvers.
Scoring: Judges evaluate the approach, execution of twists and somersaults, and entry into the water with minimal splash.

variations.title: 10m Platform Diving
variations.desc:
Athletes dive from a solid platform 10 meters above the water. With no spring action, height is generated purely by the athlete's push-off.
Key Skills: Power, precision, and body control to execute flips and twists from a greater height.
Scoring: Judges focus on form during takeoff, aerial execution, and clean water entry.

variations.title: Synchronized 3m Springboard Diving
variations.desc:
Two divers perform the same dive from separate springboards, aiming for perfect synchronization.
Key Skills: Timing, coordination, and synchronization between the divers, along with individual dive technique.
Scoring: Scores reflect both the execution of the dive and the synchronization of the athletes.

variations.title: Synchronized 10m Platform Diving:
variations.desc:
Similar to the synchronized springboard event, but performed from the 10m platform.
Key Skills: Timing and synchronization in a high-difficulty event, with emphasis on both athletes mirroring each other's movements in the air.
Scoring: Judges evaluate synchronization and individual execution of the dive.

synchronized_swim.subtitle1: Synchronized Swimming (now called Artistic Swimming) combines swimming, dance, and gymnastics, where athletes perform intricate, choreographed routines in the water to music. The sport demands strength, endurance, flexibility, grace, and precise timing, with athletes needing to perform both underwater and above the surface.
synchronized_swim.desc1:
Synchronized Swimming (now called Artistic Swimming) combines swimming, dance, and gymnastics, where athletes perform intricate, choreographed routines in the water to music. The sport demands strength, endurance, flexibility, grace, and precise timing, with athletes needing to perform both underwater and above the surface.

Routines: Both events consist of technical and free routines. The technical routine includes required elements, while the free routine allows more creativity and expression.

Judging: Judges award points for technical execution (precision of movements, difficulty) and artistic impression (creativity, choreography, and synchronization with the music).

Underwater Skills: Athletes must hold their breath for extended periods while maintaining graceful movements underwater.

Synchronized swimming demands exceptional athleticism, with athletes needing to master both endurance and artistry to execute flawless routines.

variations.title: Synchronized Swimming (Duet) - 2
variations.desc:
Two swimmers perform a choreographed routine set to music, showcasing synchronization and artistry.
Key Skills: Precise synchronization between the swimmers, strong technical execution, flexibility, and creative expression.
Scoring: Judges score based on technical merit (execution of movements, lifts, and transitions) and artistic impression (choreography, creativity, and musical interpretation). Synchronization between the two swimmers is crucial.

variations.title: Synchronized Swimming (Team) - 8
variations.desc:
A team of eight swimmers performs a routine set to music, often featuring complex patterns, lifts, and formations.
Key Skills: Perfect coordination among all team members, strength in executing lifts and stunts, endurance, and synchronization in both large and small groups.
Scoring: Teams are judged on their technical execution, synchronization, and artistic impression. The complexity of formations, transitions, and lifts adds to the difficulty and potential scoring.

athletics.subtitle1: Athletics is a collection of sporting events that involve running, jumping, throwing, and walking. It is one of the most popular and diverse categories in the world of sports, featuring events that test speed, strength, endurance, and technique. Athletics competitions can be held both indoors and outdoors, with the Olympics and World Championships being the premier events.
athletics.desc1:
False Starts: In sprints, a false start occurs when an athlete leaves the starting blocks before the gun sounds, resulting in disqualification.

Throws and Jumps: Athletes must perform within designated areas. In jumps, they must not cross the takeoff board, and in throws, they must not step outside the circle or foul line.

Relays: The baton must be passed within a specific exchange zone.

Scoring
Most track events are decided by time, with the fastest finisher winning the race.
In field events, the winner is determined by the longest valid throw or jump.
In combined events, points are awarded for performance in each event, and the athlete with the highest total score wins.

Athletics tests a wide range of physical attributes, including speed, endurance, power, and agility, making it a core part of major global sporting competitions.

Main Categories of Athletics

Track Events
Sprints (e.g., 100m, 200m, 400m): Short-distance races that focus on speed.
Middle-Distance Races (e.g., 800m, 1500m): Races that test a combination of speed and endurance.
Long-Distance Races (e.g., 5000m, 10000m, Marathon): Endurance races over longer distances.
Hurdles (e.g., 100m hurdles, 400m hurdles): Runners must clear obstacles placed at regular intervals on the track.
Relays (e.g., 4x100m, 4x400m): Teams of four runners each complete part of the distance before passing the baton to the next runner.

Field Events

Jumps
Long Jump and Triple Jump: Athletes jump for distance after a running start.
High Jump and Pole Vault: Athletes must clear a bar set at increasing heights.

Throws
Shot Put, Discus Throw, Javelin Throw, and Hammer Throw: Athletes aim to throw an object as far as possible.


Combined Events
Decathlon (Men) and Heptathlon (Women): Multi-event competitions that include a combination of track and field events testing overall athletic ability.

Race Walking: Athletes must walk as fast as possible over long distances (e.g., 20km, 50km), maintaining contact with the ground at all times.

variations.title: Sprint 100m
variations.desc: The shortest sprint race, requiring explosive speed over a straight 100 meters.

variations.title: Sprint 200m
variations.desc: A sprint around half the track, combining speed with the ability to navigate the curve.

variations.title: Sprint 400m
variations.desc: A full lap sprint, balancing speed and endurance.

variations.title: Middle-Distance Race 800m
variations.desc: A middle-distance race, typically run in two laps with a focus on speed and strategy.

variations.title: Middle-Distance Race 1500m
variations.desc: A "metric mile" requiring endurance, strategy, and a strong finish.

variations.title: Long-Distance Race 5000m
variations.desc: A long-distance race of 12.5 laps, focusing on endurance and pacing.

variations.title: Long-Distance Race 10 000m
variations.desc: A 25-lap race demanding exceptional endurance and strategic pacing.

variations.title: Marathon
variations.desc: A 42.195 km race, testing long-distance endurance over varied terrain.

variations.title: 110m Hurdles
variations.desc: A sprint with 10 hurdles spaced evenly over 110 meters, requiring speed and precise technique.

variations.title: 400m Hurdles
variations.desc: A full lap race with 10 hurdles, combining sprinting with hurdle technique.

variations.title: 3000m Steeplechase
variations.desc: A race involving barriers and water jumps, testing agility and endurance.

variations.title: 4x100m Relay
variations.desc: A team event with four runners, each sprinting 100 meters, requiring efficient baton exchanges.

variations.title: 4x400m Relay
variations.desc: A team relay where each runner covers 400 meters, with a focus on speed and strategic handovers.

variations.title: 20km Race Walk
variations.desc: A long-distance event where walkers must keep one foot in contact with the ground at all times.

variations.title: 50km Race Walk
variations.desc: An extended race walk requiring significant stamina and technique.

variations.title: High Jump
variations.desc: Athletes leap over a horizontal bar using a Fosbury Flop or other technique.

variations.title: Pole Vault
variations.desc: Competitors use a pole to vault over a bar, requiring strength, speed, and technique.

variations.title: Long Jump
variations.desc: Athletes perform a running leap for maximum horizontal distance.

variations.title: Triple Jump
variations.desc: A sequence of three phases (hop, step, jump) aiming for the longest distance.

variations.title: Shot Put
variations.desc: A throwing event where athletes propel a heavy ball for maximum distance.

variations.title: Discus Throw
variations.desc: Competitors throw a disc for maximum distance using a rotational technique.

variations.title: Hammer Throw
variations.desc: Athletes spin and throw a heavy weight attached to a wire for distance.

variations.title: Javelin Throw
variations.desc: A spear-like javelin is thrown for maximum distance, emphasizing technique and speed.

variations.title: Decathlon
variations.desc: A ten-event competition combining sprints, jumps, throws, and distance events.

badminton.subtitle1: Badminton is a fast-paced racket sport played either in singles (one player per side) or doubles (two players per side). The objective is to hit the shuttlecock over the net and land it in the opponent’s court, scoring points when the opponent fails to return the shuttlecock within the boundaries.
badminton.desc1:
Scoring: Matches are typically best-of-three games. Each game is played to 21 points, with players scoring a point on every rally (rally scoring system). A two-point lead is required to win a game, with a cap at 30 points.

Serve: The server must hit the shuttlecock diagonally into the opponent’s service box. The serve must be delivered below the waist, and in singles, the serve must land in the narrower service area.

Rallies: Players rally by hitting the shuttlecock back and forth. The rally ends when the shuttlecock touches the ground, goes out of bounds, or fails to cross the net.

Faults: A fault occurs if the shuttlecock is hit into the net, out of bounds, or if the player makes an illegal shot, such as a double hit or carrying the shuttle.



Types of Shots:

  • Smash: A powerful downward shot aimed at winning the point.
  • Drop Shot: A delicate shot that just clears the net and drops into the opponent's court.
  • Clear: A high, deep shot that forces the opponent to the back of the court.
  • Drive: A fast, flat shot parallel to the ground.


Singles vs Doubles:

  • Singles: Played one-on-one, focusing on speed, stamina, and court coverage.
  • Doubles: Played two-on-two, with greater emphasis on teamwork, strategy, and quick reflexes. The court is wider, and players often specialize in either front or backcourt play.


    • Court and Equipment:

      • Court: A rectangular court divided by a net. Singles courts are narrower (5.18 meters wide), while doubles courts are wider (6.1 meters).
      • Net: Positioned at the center, 1.55 meters high.
      • Shuttlecock: A feathered or synthetic projectile used in place of a ball, designed to decelerate quickly when hit.
      Racket: Lightweight rackets are used to strike the shuttlecock.


Badminton requires agility, quick reflexes, and excellent hand-eye coordination. It is played internationally at events such as the Olympics, World Championships, and the prestigious All England Open.

variations.title: Singles Badminton
variations.desc:
• Event: One player competes against another player.
  • Competition Method: Each player uses a racket to hit the shuttlecock over the net, aiming to land it within the opponent’s court. The match is played in a best-of-three games format, with each game played to 21 points. Players must win by at least 2 points.
  • Key Rules:
    • Serving: The serve must be diagonal and hit below the server's waist.
    • Scoring: Points are awarded when the opponent fails to return the shuttlecock or hits it out of bounds.

Court: The court for singles is 13.4 meters long and 5.18 meters wide.

variations.title: Doubles Badminton
variations.desc:
• Event: Two teams of two players each compete against each other.
    • Competition Method: Teams use rackets to hit the shuttlecock over the net, aiming to land it within the opponent’s court. Matches are played in a best-of-three games format, with each game played to 21 points. Teams must win by at least 2 points.
    • Key Rules:
      • Serving: The serve must be diagonal and hit below the server's waist. Players alternate serving within their team.
      • Scoring: Points are awarded when the opposing team fails to return the shuttlecock or hits it out of bounds.
      • Court: The court for doubles is 13.4 meters long and 6.1 meters wide. The wider width accommodates the extra player on each side.

basketball.subtitle1: Basketball is a fast-paced team sport played on a rectangular court, where two teams of five players each aim to score points by shooting a ball through the opponent's hoop, which is mounted 10 feet high. The team with the most points at the end of the game wins
basketball.desc1:
Court and Equipment:

  • Court: A rectangular surface with two baskets located at each end. Key areas include the three-point line, free-throw line, and the paint (key area).

  • Basket: A metal rim with a net, elevated 10 feet off the ground.

  • Ball: An orange, leather or composite basketball used for dribbling, passing, and shooting.

Key Rules:

  1. Scoring:

    • Field Goals: Worth 2 points when made inside the three-point line.

    • Three-Pointers: Worth 3 points when made from beyond the three-point line.

    • Free Throws: Worth 1 point each, awarded for fouls committed during shooting attempts.

  2. Game Duration: Typically four quarters, each lasting 12 minutes (NBA) or 10 minutes (FIBA), with overtime played if the score is tied at the end of regulation.

  3. Possession and Play:

    • Dribbling: Players must dribble the ball while moving; failure to do so results in a traveling violation.

    • Passing: Players can pass the ball to teammates to advance it or set up scoring opportunities.

    • Shot Clock: Teams must attempt a shot within a specific time (24 seconds in the NBA, 30 seconds in FIBA).

  4. Fouls:

    • Personal Fouls: Committed when illegal physical contact occurs, leading to free throws or ball possession for the opponent.

    • Technical Fouls: Given for unsportsmanlike behavior or rule infractions.

Team Fouls: When a team commits too many fouls in a period, the opposing team gets free throws.

boxing.subtitle1: Boxing is a combat sport where two athletes, known as boxers, compete in a ring using only their fists to land punches on their opponent while following a set of strict rules. The primary goal is to outscore the opponent by landing clean punches or to win by knockout (KO), where one boxer is unable to continue..
boxing.desc1:
Key Aspects of Boxing:

  1. Rounds and Duration:

    • Professional boxing typically consists of 12 rounds, each lasting 3 minutes, with a 1-minute rest between rounds.

    • Amateur matches often consist of 3 to 4 rounds.

  2. Scoring:

    • Judges score each round based on clean, effective punches landed, defensive skills, and ring control. The boxer with the higher score at the end of the match wins, unless the fight ends by knockout or technical knockout.

  3. Knockout (KO) and Technical Knockout (TKO):

    • A KO occurs when a boxer is knocked down and cannot rise before the referee counts to ten.

    • A TKO happens when the referee deems a boxer unable to continue the fight, even if they are still on their feet.

  4. Protective Gear:

    • Boxers wear padded gloves to protect their hands and limit injury to their opponents.

    • Mouthguards are required to protect the teeth and jaws.

    • Headgear is worn in amateur boxing for additional protection.

  5. Weight Classes:

    • Boxers compete in weight divisions to ensure fair competition, ranging from lightweight to heavyweight, each with a specific weight limit.

Tactics and Skills:

  • Offensive Skills: Boxers use jabs, hooks, uppercuts, and body shots to target their opponent.

  • Defense: Effective boxing includes blocking, slipping punches, and footwork to evade strikes.

  • Strategy: Boxers must balance aggression with defense, adapting their style to outmaneuver their opponent.

Boxing requires a blend of physical fitness, mental toughness, and tactical thinking, making it a highly disciplined and strategic sport.

Weight Classes:

  1. Lightweight (< TBD kg):

    • Boxers in this class are known for their speed, agility, and stamina. They rely on quick footwork, fast combinations, and endurance to outpoint or overwhelm their opponents.

  2. Mediumweight (< TBD kg):

    • A balance of speed and power defines this class. Boxers here combine tactical precision with the ability to land heavier punches, making their bouts a mix of skill and strength.

  3. Heavyweight (> TBD kg):

    • Known for their size and knockout power, heavyweights rely on strength and powerful blows. These boxers may be slower compared to lighter categories, but their punches are extremely forceful, often deciding bouts with fewer hits.

Boxing Rules:

  • Matches consist of a series of rounds, typically 3 minutes each, with a 1-minute rest between rounds.

  • A bout can end by knockout (KO), technical knockout (TKO), or by decision, where judges score based on the number of clean punches landed, defense, and ring control.

  • Boxers must wear protective gear such as gloves, mouthguards, and sometimes headgear (in amateur boxing).

Boxing tests endurance, strategy, and precision, with each weight class bringing its own unique style of competition.
